author: Fred Lambert
title: Tesla announces new partnership with Samsung over energy connectivity | Electrek
text:
Tesla and Samsung have announced a new partnership over energy connectivity, which appears to be the reason behind Teslaâ€™s API update.
Yesterday, we reported on Tesla updating their API to include Powerwall, solar, and Wall Connector integration.
It looks like the update was in the works because of a new collaboration with Samsung.
Just a day later, Samsung released this new press release announcing the partnership:
Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. today announced that it has established a service integration with Tesla, to be showcased at CES Â® 2024, that will connect SmartThings Energy to Tesla products such as Powerwall home battery, Solar Inverter, Wall Connector charging solutions and electric vehicles (EVs). Made possible through Teslaâ€™s open APIs 1 , this collaboration will result in the further expansion of SmartThings Energyâ€™s already-comprehensive level of connectivity and contribute to Samsungâ€™s ultimate goal of enabling more convenient, seamless home experiences for consumers.
It sounds like Samsung is going to enable monitoring of Tesla energy products through its own app.
Chanwoo Park, EVP and Head of IoT Development Team of Device Platform Center at Samsung Electronics, commented on the new collaboration:
â€œTesla Energyâ€™s customers can now manage and monitor the power status of their homes through SmartThings Energy and Samsung devices in addition to the Tesla app, ensuring more access and connectivity. â€œThis new collaboration is a key milestone for Samsung Electronics in making our solution more widely available beyond home appliances.â€
It appears that the collaboration is still only at an early stage and that more is going to come over time.
For now, Samsung also says that Tesla is going to be able to push its â€œStorm Watchâ€ notifications through Samsung smart TVs.
The electronics giant also makes it sounds like it could automatically shut down some devices when Teslaâ€™s energy systems start using backup power in order to prolong the capacity to operate off-grid.
Add Electrek to your Google News feed.

author: Imani Fleming
title: Trial begins for man accused of letting child drown in bathtub
text:
Trial begins for man accused of leaving child to drown in motel bathtub
A man accused of leaving a 1-year-old girl to drown in a bathtub in Manchester more than five years ago is now on trial.
In opening statements Wednesday, prosecutors said Zachary Conway was careless and high on drugs when the child drowned.
Conway's attorneys said there's no denying that the girl's death was tragic, but they said it was an accident. Defense attorneys said Conway was not under the influence of drugs when the child drowned, but he was sick and being treated for pneumonia.
"We're not going to be able to say this wasn't tragic," said defense attorney Mark Sisti. "But you know what we can say? It wasn't criminal."
>> Download the free WMUR app to get updates on the go: Apple | Google Play <<
Prosecutors said Conway was under the influence of marijuana when he put the child he was caring for that night in a bathtub at an Econo Lodge in Manchester. They said he fell asleep while she was in the tub, and he found her there, dead, after he woke up.
"The defendant's conduct was far and away from what a reasonable person would have done in the same situation," said prosecutor Zachary Charland. "Because the defendant failed to supervise Stella, because of his negligence, she drowned."
The child's mother and Conway had a relationship at one point, and the jury also heard from her Wednesday. Defense attorneys said she doesn't believe Conway was high when her daughter drowned.
Prosecutors told the jury that they do not have to prove intent in a negligent homicide case, while Conway's attorneys asked the jury to keep their minds open as the trial moves forward.

author: @adndotcom
title: If you didnâ€™t share a recap video, did 2023 even happen? - Anchorage Daily News
text: When Joseph Arujo, a 20-year-old content creator and student in Los Angeles, began seeing 2023 recap videos in his feed last month, he began scouring his hard drive for content. He hunted down old photos and videos and compiled them in a video for TikTok. 2023 recap videos were â€œeverywhere,â€ he said. In yearly recap videos, you - or your friends, cousins, or people you barely know - string together dozens of videos and photos from the past 12 months, often set to the beat of a trending audio track. This new year, theyâ€™ve become an online phenomenon, allowing users an outlet to reflect while also generating anxiety and pressure among young people to commodify their lives into viral content. The trend also shows how the content formats and behavior of professional influencers are increasingly being adopted by average users. [@taylorlorenz] Who do we suddenly talk about our lives as â€œseasonsâ€? And if you didnâ€™t share a cinematic highlight reel, did 2023 even happen? Over the past several years apps and social platforms have given rise to the recap industrial complex. In 2016, an app called Top Nine went viral, allowing Instagram users to share a grid of their top 9 posts. That same year Spotify introduced Spotify Wrapped, a personalized round up of each userâ€™s listening activity. Strava, a social fitness app, now provides users with an annual report of their fitness activity, and Goodreads, a platform for book lovers, offers a â€œYear in Booksâ€ feature summarizing usersâ€™ reading accomplishments. On TikTok, yearly recap videos became popular with high-profile content creators, eventually trickling down to average users. â€œYou're getting a recap fed to you in every form of content,â€ said one creator. Yearly recap videos have become an online phenomenon, allowing users an outlet to reflect while also generating anxiety and pressure among young people to commodify their lives into viral content. The ideas that one should romanticize their life, be the main character and treat life like a movie have become commonplace on TikTok. So itâ€™s no surprise that users would begin regurgitating their memories into cinematic edits. The explosion of 2023 recap videos shows, â€œthe TikTokification of life,â€ said Kate Lindsay, co-founder of the internet culture newsletter Embedded. â€œNew Yearâ€™s is already a reflective time, itâ€™s a time to look back. And now social media takes it to the next level.â€ Read my full story in The Washington Post!! ðŸŽ† [#capcut] [#tiktok] [#trends] [#culture] [#technology] [#tech] [#genz] [#content] [#contentcreator] [#influencer] [#commentary] [#womanintech] [#siliconvalley] [#apps] [#2023] [#2023recap] [#socialmedia] [#online] [#internetculture] [#CapCut] [â™¬ Clocks - Coldplay] â€œI think this phenomenon strongly relates to the sentiment that, â€˜if you didnâ€™t post it, is it even real?â€™â€ said Jules Terpak, a content creator who makes videos about digital culture. â€œPeople . . . not only have to document their years for others, but for their future selves to take in the significance of the year.â€ Videos including the hashtag #2023recap have amassed a collective 1.6 billion views on TikTok. â€œ2023 recapâ€ was listed as one of the most popular searches on Instagram in the days leading up to New Yearâ€™s Eve. Snapchat is incentivizing recap video creation by prompting users to create TikTok-like 2023 recap videos for the app. â€œEveryone wants to show their life looking the best that it can,â€ said Annie Wu Henry, a digital strategist in Philadelphia, â€œand that now includes . . . these videos.â€ Apps have begun making it easier to package the year into a digestible format for a while now. In 2016, an app called Top Nine went viral, allowing Instagram users to share a grid of their top 9 posts. That same year Spotify introduced Spotify Wrapped, a personalized round up of each userâ€™s listening activity. Strava, a social fitness app, now provides users with an annual report of their fitness activity, and Goodreads, a platform for book lovers, offers a â€œYear in Booksâ€ feature summarizing usersâ€™ reading accomplishments. On TikTok, yearly recap videos became popular with high-profile content creators, eventually trickling down to average users. â€œYouâ€™re getting a recap fed to you in every form of content,â€ said Arujo. The ideas that one should romanticize their life, be the main character and treat life like a movie have become commonplace on TikTok. So itâ€™s no surprise that users would begin regurgitating their memories into cinematic highlight reels. â€œWe have democratized being a content creator where now even your aunt is posting an app downloaded slide show of videos that summarized her year,â€ said Luke Anderson, a producer in Los Angeles. The rise in 2023 recap videos shows, â€œthe TikTokification of life,â€ said Kate Lindsay, co-founder of the internet culture newsletter Embedded. â€œNew Yearâ€™s is already a reflective time, itâ€™s a time to look back. And now social media takes it to the next level.â€ From a technical standpoint, highly produced recap videos are also becoming easier to create. CapCut, a video editing platform owned by ByteDance, provides easily replicable video creation formats that can be directly posted to TikTok, including several 2023 recap templates. â€œCapCut templates make it easier to create this content, period,â€ said Rachel Greenspan, a social media strategist in New York. Lindsay added that there are almost as many viral tutorials teaching users how to create their own 2023 recap videos, as the viral recap videos themselves. However as year-end recap videos have skyrocketed in popularity, the format has also led to increased pressure among users. Several people on social media told The Post that they felt frustrated and overwhelmed at the prospect of summarizing an entire year into engaging short-form content. Julia Metraux, a journalist in San Francisco said that she created a recap video only to delete it, worrying that the quality wasnâ€™t up to par. Bryant Rodriguez, a content strategist in Southern California also said he also felt overwhelmed by the trend. After seeing the videos take over his feeds, he considered making his own. â€œI kept trying to come up with a plan for how to do it,â€ he said. â€œIt ended up just creating more anxiety.â€ Rodriguez struggled with who and what to include in his roundup, and worried about offending a friend by leaving someone out. â€œLast year I didnâ€™t feel this pressure,â€ he said. Leo Velazquez, a corporate trainer for an insurance company in Orange County, said that he witnessed a friend having a crisis over his 2023 recap video. His friend posted on Instagram Story saying that it took him 17 edits to create his final 2023 recap video after losing footage in between versions. Velazquez felt like the whole process seemed like too much, and since he hadnâ€™t traveled much in 2023, he didnâ€™t feel like he had any good content. â€œThereâ€™s so much effort into posting these videos,â€ he said. Those who did create videos, such as India Daykin, a brand manager in Vancouver, said that they did so mostly as a way to engage in a bit of nostalgia. â€œEven though these trends are kind of silly, itâ€™s an interesting opportunity to force yourself to reflect on more positive moments throughout your year,â€ she said. While most 2023 recap videos are aspirational, filled with videos of partying, adventures, travel, and quality time with friends and loved ones, some TikTok users have leveraged the format to share low points in their lives in the past year, such as dealing with chronic illness or to reflect on the ongoing covid-19 pandemic and the war in the Middle East. â€œI think with such lows [this year], even just surviving gives a bit of nostalgia,â€ Metraux said. As the format grows in popularity, meme pages have also begun to create recap videos focused on more outward facing world events. â€œThereâ€™s so much tragedy that happened this year from covid, to the earthquakes in Afghanistan, to the wildfires in Maui, to the situation in Gaza,â€ said the administrator of the Political Compass, a popular meme page on Instagram. â€œLiterally so much has happened, and it seems like a recap video . . . is the best way to memorialize it all,â€ While CapCut makes creating yearly recap videos easier, Sheel Mohnot, a venture capitalist in San Francisco, said that soon AI tools may allow people to create such videos with the click of a button. Heâ€™s surprised that Instagram hadnâ€™t already created an easy way to create recaps. â€œI feel like Instagram should give you a year in review like Spotify does,â€ he said. Others avoided posting their recap content on social media altogether, instead choosing to share highlights from the past year in person with family or a select group of friends. Jordan Lucero, a 17-year-old high school junior in Oklahoma City spent his New Yearâ€™s Eve displaying a month by month PowerPoint presentation recapping his past year to a group of friends. â€œPeople want to be more self-aware and reflect on stuff, and a lot of these things just get hidden away in our photo library,â€ he said. â€œI think itâ€™s a positive thing to go back and process the year in a fun way.â€ Recaps can also provide a useful introduction to someoneâ€™s life. Lucero said that his friend had a new boyfriend, and he planned to show their yearly recap on New Yearâ€™s Eve. â€œWe have to get him caught up on our lore,â€ Lucero said. Taylor Lorenz is a columnist at The Washington Post covering technology and online culture. Before joining The Post, she was a technology reporter for the New York Times. Previously, she was a technology reporter at the Atlantic and the Daily Beast.
